<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 277, 228, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 903, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/61  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 301, 339, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[770, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 384, 392, 399]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 665, 211, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 728, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
1 It is known that \(1 \%\) of houses in a certain area have a wind turbine. A random sample of 400 houses in this area is chosen for a survey on domestic heating. The number of houses in the sample that have a wind turbine is denoted by \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 581, 153]]<|/det|>
Use a suitable approximating distribution to find \(\mathrm{P}(X \leqslant 3)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 82, 99, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 78, 918, 116]]<|/det|>
2 The random variable \(X\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{B}\left(8, \frac{3}{4}\right)\). A random sample of 100 values of \(X\) is chosen, and the sample mean, \(\overline{X}\), is found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 131, 144, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 128, 700, 147]]<|/det|>
(a) Find \(\mathrm{P}(\overline{X}>6.2)\). You are not expected to use a continuity correction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 765, 144, 782]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 763, 769, 782]]<|/det|>
(b) State why the Central Limit Theorem was needed in the calculation in part (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
3 The time, \(T\) minutes, for a certain daily bus journey is normally distributed. The bus company claims that the mean of \(T\) is 45 . A passenger believes that the mean of \(T\) is actually greater than 45 . She notes the times taken for this journey on a random sample of 60 days. The results are summarised below.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 131, 688, 153]]<|/det|>
\[
n=60 \quad \sum t=2750 \quad \sum t^{2}=127000
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 168, 144, 185]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 166, 675, 185]]<|/det|>
(a) Calculate unbiased estimates of the population mean and variance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 477, 144, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 475, 588, 494]]<|/det|>
(b) Test the passenger's belief at the \(5 \%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
4 At an entertainment centre, the cost for using a particular video game is \(\$ 0.40\) per minute. The number of minutes for which people use the video game has mean 15 and variance 9 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 121, 144, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 121, 777, 139]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the mean and variance of the amount people pay for using the video game.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 520, 551, 537]]<|/det|>
<pre>Each day, 35 people independently use the video game.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 552, 144, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 552, 672, 570]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the mean and variance of the total amount paid by 35 people.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 76, 144, 93]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
5 (a) The random variables \(W\) and \(X\) have the independent distributions \(\mathrm{Po}(1.2)\) and \(\mathrm{Po}(2.3)\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 107, 185, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 106, 386, 123]]<|/det|>
(i) Find \(\mathrm{P}(3 \leqslant W+X \leqslant 5)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 320, 915, 338]]<|/det|>
<pre>The random variable \(S\) is the sum of 100 independent values of \(W\) and 200 independent values of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 352, 188, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 351, 586, 369]]<|/det|>
(ii) Use a suitable approximation to find \(\mathrm{P}(S>600)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 77, 144, 93]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 660, 93]]<|/det|>
(b) The random variable \(Y\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(\lambda)\), where \(\lambda>0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 100, 551, 127]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\frac{5}{2} \mathrm{P}(Y=3)+\mathrm{P}(Y=4)=\mathrm{P}(Y=5)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 136, 314, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\lambda\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 138]]<|/det|>
6 A manufacturer of cell phones claims that \(25 \%\) of students own a Pumpkin phone. Jeyeraj thinks that the proportion of students at his large college who own a Pumpkin phone is less than \(25 \%\). He plans to test the manufacturer's claim. He chooses a random sample of 30 students at his college. If the number of students who own a Pumpkin phone is less than 5 , Jeyeraj will reject the manufacturer's claim.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 152, 144, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 151, 447, 168]]<|/det|>
(a) State suitable hypotheses for the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 337, 144, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 336, 918, 369]]<|/det|>
(b) Given that the true proportion of students at the college who own a Pumpkin phone is \(10 \%\), use a binomial distribution to find the probability of a Type II error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 900, 91]]<|/det|>
<pre>At Florence's college, in a random sample of 40 students, it was found that 5 own a Pumpkin phone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 106, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 104, 918, 138]]<|/det|>
(c) Calculate an approximate \(95 \%\) confidence interval for the proportion of students at Florence's college who own a Pumpkin phone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 628, 91]]<|/det|>
7 \(X\) is a random variable with probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 106, 648, 145]]<|/det|>
\[
\mathrm{f}(x)= \begin{cases}(1+\cos \pi x) & 0 \leqslant x \leqslant 1 \\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 166, 144, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 160, 398, 189]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that \(\mathrm{P}\left(X<\frac{1}{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{\pi}\).

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 567, 89]]<|/det|>
# Additional page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
